posts.name: Ample Hills Creamery
posts.note: Ample Hills Creamery offers creative small-batch ice cream made with local ingredients. They use hormone free milk and cream from grass fed cows and organic cane sugar. If you like salted caramel ice cream you need to try their Salted Crack Caramel.

posts.name: Big Gay Ice Cream Shop
posts.note: With a playful attitude, Big Gay Ice Cream spins a new take on old-school soft-serve by creating fun and unique ice creams, toppings, and frozen treats that appeal to a diverse mix of clientele.

posts.name: Cafe Orlin
posts.note: Longtime cafe serving American and Middle Eastern food, best enjoyed on the streetside patio and have a great weekend brunch.

posts.name: Carnegie Deli
posts.note: At this old-school deli, diners fill up on pastrami, corned beef, matzoh balls & other staples.

posts.name: Chelsea Market *
posts.note: Chelsea Market is a food hall, shopping mall, office building and television production facility located in the Chelsea neighborhood of the borough of Manhattan, in New York City.

posts.name: Cocoron *
posts.note: Broth-based soba and sake highlight the menu of this small, unpretentious Japanese noodle shop.

posts.name: Crif Dogs
posts.note: Hot dogs with creative toppings and late-night hours make this spot a natural for post-bar munchies.

posts.name: Doughnut Plant
posts.note: Making doughnuts by hand with the highest quality all natural ingredients since 1994.

posts.name: Eataly
posts.note: They love high-quality food and drink. They love the stories about it, the people who produce it, and the places it comes from.

posts.name: Haandi *
posts.note: Bare-bones cafeteria serving Indian and Pakistani eats that claim a loyal taxi-driver following. People recommend order the goat head.

posts.name: The Halal Guys
posts.note: Once you have had a taste, you will understand why New Yorkers and tourists alike have stood in the city’s longest food cart line (sometimes for hours) to get a hot, steaming platter of chicken or gyro over rice, covered in The Halal Guys famous, proprietary White Sauce. Can't go wrong with the chicken and lamb over rice.

posts.name: Ippudo Ramen
posts.note: Ippudo East Village is the first international Ippudo to introduce the World to authentic Hakata tonkotsu pork soup.

posts.name: Ivan Ramen Slurp Shop
posts.note: Besides ramen, this noodle counter in Gotham West Market serves rice bowls and sides.

posts.name: J.G. Melon *
posts.note: They've been around since 1972 is a mark of quality in the New York restaurant market, which is extremely competitive.

posts.name: Katz’s Delicatessen *
posts.note: No-frills deli with theatrically cranky service serving mile-high sandwiches since 1888.

posts.name: Kunjip *
posts.note: Bustling, 24/7 staple doling out seafood pancakes, bibimbop and other Korean items in a basic setting. Open 24 hours a day.

posts.name: Levain Bakery *
posts.note: Cozy neighborhood bakery where locals are greeted by name. A steady stream of loyal regulars stand side by side with tourists, eager to sample the legendary baked goods.

posts.name: The Meatball Shop
posts.note: Fast casual service restaurant specializing in meatballs with 6 locations in New York City.

posts.name: Miss KOREA MEE *
posts.note: Chic, zen-like Koreatown restaurant for barbecue, bulgogi and hot pots. Open 24 hours a day.

posts.name: New Wonjo
posts.note: Always-open Korean BBQ mainstay distinguishing itself with charcoal-fueled grills. Open 24 hours a day.

posts.name: Russ & Daughters *
posts.note: Specializes in caviar, smoked fish, herring, bagels and elegant food gifts. Also offers catering services.

posts.name: Sake Bar Hagi *
posts.note: Vibrant, open-late downstairs den offering a large menu of Japanese bites plus beer and sake.

posts.name: Salt and Pepper
posts.note: Casual eatery displaying ample hot American, Spanish, Indian and Pakistani dishes. I have found the Indian and Pakistani food to be the best such as the curry lamb or goat with chickpeas over rice.

posts.name: Sobakoh *
posts.note: Chefs make soba noodles behind a display window at this refined Japanese eatery.

posts.name: Spicy Village *
posts.note: Chinese cafe serving Henan fare (hand-pulled noodles, pork pancakes & spicy chicken) in simple digs. The big dish is the chicken.

posts.name: Tori Shin *
posts.note: Sophisticated Japanese eatery offering charcoal-grilled skewers and sake, plus a chef's-choice option. They are recommended by Izakaya Seki in DC.

posts.name: Torrisi Italian Specialties *
posts.note: A seasonal, prix fixe-only Italian-American menu packs patrons into a cozy, exposed brick setting.

posts.name: Village Yokocho *
posts.note: Chill second-floor eatery serving home-style Japanese fare in an evocative space. Friends say it's awesome yakitori (skewered meat).

posts.name: Yakitori Oh Taisho *
posts.note: Late-night hours and yakitori (meat on a skewer) keep this East Village Japanese joint bustling.

posts.name: Yakitori Totto *
posts.note: Upstairs Japanese yakitori spot transporting diners to Tokyo via grilled skewers & a bustling scene.

posts.name: Zabars *
posts.note: Iconic store known for smoked fish, plus a huge variety of gourmet goods, prepared foods and cookware.

posts.name: Zaragoza Mexican Deli & Grocery *
posts.note: Pint-sized market with basic Mexican staples & a counter serving classic take-out eats like tacos. Order whatever is on special.

posts.name: Zucker's Bagels and Smoked Fish
posts.note: Bagels (plus a wide selection of toppings), smoked fish, sandwiches & more in a bustling space.
